name: (2R)-Hydroxy(phenyl)acetic acid
Reason: The target compound, (2R)-hydroxy(phenyl)acetic acid, can be broken down into several functional groups starting from the base structure of benzene. The basic unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. The phenolic hydroxyl group will generally increase the melting point due to its ability to participate in hydrogen bonding, potentially adding around +70 to +100 degrees Celsius. The adjacent carboxylic acid group will have an even more substantial impact due to its capacity for strong hydrogen bonding, possibly contributing an additional +100 to +150 degrees Celsius. Additionally, the acetic acid side chain will also modestly raise the melting point with an increment of around +10 to +30 degrees Celsius due to the increased molecular weight and hydrogen bonding ability. However, the impact of the racemic mixture configuration on melting point is not quantifiable without details on the purity of enantiomers and the possibility of racemate formation which can lead to higher or lower melting points than individual isomers.
Prediction: The predicted melting point considering the benzene base structure (+5.5), the influence of the phenolic hydroxyl group (+85 on average), the carboxylic acid group (+125 on average), and the acetic acid side chain (+20 on average) would be approximately: 5.5 (benzene) + 85 (hydroxyl group) + 125 (carboxylic acid group) + 20 (acetic acid side chain) = 235.5 degrees Celsius.
